meanings.def: to look at and understand the meaning of written or printed words or symbols
examples: She's still learning to read.
Some children can read and write before they go to school.
read something I can't read your writing.
Can you read music?
I'm trying to read the map.
She can read Arabic, but she can't speak it.
A saxophone is another instrument that uses a reed.
He speaks and reads Arabic fluently.
Most children can read by the age of seven.
She had great difficulty learning to read and write.
He learned to read when he was three.
Some of the kids here can't even read and write.

meanings.def: to go through written or printed words, etc. in silence or speaking them to other people
examples: I'm going to go to bed and read.
The book is very easy to read.
read to somebody/yourself He liked reading to his grandchildren.
read something to read a book/magazine/newspaper
to read an article/a report/a letter/a blog/a review
Have you read any Steinbeck (= novels by him)?
one of the most widely read books in the world
I have read every single post in this entire thread.
I didn't have time to read the novel.
I just finished reading your recent article.
He read the poem aloud.
read something to somebody/yourself Go on—read it to us.
Statements were read to the court from police officers.
read somebody something She read us a story.
Have you read his new novel yet?
She's that girl over there in the red dress.
The red of the setting sun glowed on the horizon.
I read the words out loud.
Will you read me a story?
What are you reading at the moment?
She reads voraciously.
I used to read to my younger brothers at bedtime.
Could you read the poem aloud to us please?
We teach students to read critically.
She read from the letter.
She read avidly from an early age—books, magazines, anything.
I've just read your interesting article.
I regularly read ‘Time’.
I read a story to my son every night.
I listen to my children reading aloud.
He remembers everything he reads in books.
He's not someone who reads for pleasure.
He read her letter with interest.
Make sure you read the instructions correctly.

meanings.def: to discover or find out about somebody/something by reading
examples: read about/of something (in something) I read about the accident in the local paper.
read that… I read that he had resigned.
I read somewhere that women are starting companies at record rates.
read something I can't remember where I read it.
That's the most ridiculous thing I have ever read!
read something in something Don't believe everything you read in the papers.
read something on something I read the reviews on the internet.
Hogan had read about her death in the paper.
I had read of the case in the local newspaper.
I read about it in today's paper.

meanings.def: to guess what somebody else is thinking
examples: Tell me what you want—I can't read your mind!

meanings.def: to look at the movements of somebody’s lips to learn what they are saying
to understand something in a particular way
examples: read something How do you read the present situation?
read something as something Silence must not always be read as consent.

meanings.def: to have something written on it; to be written in a particular way
examples: The sign read ‘No admittance’.
I’ve changed the last paragraph. It now reads as follows…

meanings.def: to give a particular impression when read
examples: Generally, the article reads very well.
The poem reads like (= sounds as if it is) a translation.

meanings.def: to show a particular weight, pressure, etc.
examples: What does the thermometer read?

meanings.def: to get information from a measuring instrument
examples: A man came to read the gas meter.

meanings.def: to hear and understand somebody speaking on a radio set
examples: ‘Do you read me?’ ‘I'm reading you loud and clear.’

meanings.def: to replace one word, etc. with another when correcting a text
examples: For ‘madam’ in line 3 read ‘madman’.

meanings.def: to study a subject, especially at a university
examples: read something I read English at Oxford.
read for something She's reading for a law degree.

meanings.def: to take information from a disk
examples: read something My computer can't read the CD-ROM you sent.
read something into something to read a file into a computer

meanings.def: to look for or discover a meaning in something that is not openly stated
examples: Reading between the lines, I think Clare needs money.

meanings.def: to understand easily what somebody is thinking or feeling
used to tell somebody to listen carefully to what you are saying
examples: Read my lips: no new taxes (= I promise there will be no new taxes).

meanings.def: to tell somebody with force that they must not do something
to accept something without discussing it
examples: Can we take it as read that you want the job?

idioms.def: to look for or discover a meaning in something that is not openly stated
examples: Reading between the lines, I think Clare needs money.

idioms.def: to understand easily what somebody is thinking or feeling
used to tell somebody to listen carefully to what you are saying
examples: Read my lips: no new taxes (= I promise there will be no new taxes).

idioms.def: to tell somebody with force that they must not do something
to accept something without discussing it
examples: Can we take it as read that you want the job?

meanings.def: an act or a period of reading something
examples: I was having a quiet read when the phone rang.
Can I have a read of your newspaper when you’ve finished?
I know you'll enjoy the read.
The program is simple to use after a quick read of the manual.

meanings.def: a book, an article, etc. that is good, etc.
examples: His thrillers are always a gripping read.
The story made an interesting read.

meanings.def: having knowledge that has been gained from reading books, etc.
examples: She's very widely read in law.
